newsitem.title: CHINA: HK stocks seen firmer, sideways trade expected.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks seen firmer, sideways trade expected.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks are expected to open higher on Wednesday after a record close on Wall Street, but brokers said trade would drift sideways on concerns about the government's decision to increase land supply.

The government's announcement on Tuesday of a large increase in land supply over the next five years would scare some investors, said Kent Rossiter, institutional sales manager at Nikko Securities. "Overall, I think it is going to be a little bit more sideways trading than it has been," he said.
On Tuesday, the Hang Seng Index set a record closing high of 15,487.24, up 116.30 points, or 0.76 percent.
The Hang Seng London Reference Index later inched ahead by 11.39 points to 15,498.63, while the Dow industrials jumped 52.73 points to an all-time high 7,975.71.
Edwin Cheung, dealing director at Taiwan Securities, said the local market lacked impetus. He expected the blue chip index to see resistance near the 15,600 level.
"The property sector will prevent the market from making strong gains," Rossiter said.
The government said it planned to boost residential land supply by 140 percent in the five years to 2002 compared to the previous five-year period.
